sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Was not I right not to fume and fret?—Ha! ha!—I kept my temper, you ſee.—Ha! ha!—Is not it the luckieſt thing in the world?

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: [With a forc'd laugh.] Such luck never was heard of.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Wiſely—Bellfield—how do ye, lads?—Wiſely, give me joy:—I have had a moſt admirable eſcape from the galling yoke of matrimony.—I have done with the widow, my boy.

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: [In ſpirits.] Have you?

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: [Uneaſy.] Done with her!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Yes, completely:—She's a compound of deceit, affectation, treachery, and fraud.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: My dear Careleſs, ſhe's a very fine woman.—Marry her ſtiil, man.

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: You have hit her character, Careleſs. I ſhould be ſorry any friend of mine—

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Ay; I know her thoroughly.—I ſhall mortify her pride:—I'll gall her proud heart:—You'll ſee me to-morrow married to Lucinda.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: And the widow will be ſo provok'd—

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Zoons! Sir, but let me tell you—

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—You wanted me to make her amends a little while ago: I could not then; but now I'm at liberty, I ſhall certainly do it.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Sure the widow is a much finer woman.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Oh! no, no, no [laughing].

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: Not to be compar'd to her, Careleſs.—Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: I ſhall certainly marry her, Bellfield.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: But, Sir, do you imagine— [angrily.]

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: She's beautiful as an angel:—Young, accompliſh'd, elegant—

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Mr. Careleſs, what do you mean by this?

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Why, won't you let me praiſe her?—Wiſely, he was going to cut my throat a while ago, for abuſing her; and now he wants to murder me for ſpeaking in her commendation—But make yourſelf eaſy, my dear Bellfield, I ſhall marry her.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Marry her! Damnation!

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: No violence, Bellfield: Careleſs is very right [holds Bellfield.] She's a ſweet girl, Careleſs.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Yes; I know ſhe is.—Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: Marry her by all means.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Moſt certainly.—Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Let go your hold, Mr. Wiſely.—I deſire, Sir—

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Lads, for ſhame!—not ready for the ball!—Hey! what! quarrelling!—never quarrel, my dear Bellfield—never be out of humour.—Paſſion unhinges the whole frame; [turning out his toes] deſtroys the grace and gaiety, and—

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: My dear knight, you're always in good humour; give us your hand.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Always, Sir; always in ſpirits.—Bellfield, I have made a new country-dance ſince I ſaw you.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: I heard ſome bad news; and ſo I did it to ſhake off melancholy.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Bad news!—What's the matter, Sir Philip?

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p:
Poor lady Portſoken!—You know I told you I uſed to dance with her.—I received a letter, mentioning, that after a veniſon feaſt at her houſe laſt week, as ſhe was amuſing herſelf over a quart of ſyllabub, ſhe was taken ſuddenly ill, and expired [ſinks and riſes]. I was very much
ſhocked; ſo I compoſed a dance to raiſe my ſpirits.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Hang him, a troubleſome fellow.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: I am very ſorry for her, I aſſure you.—Bellfield, it's a charming dance; all briſkneſs and activity.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Po! po!

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Foot it at top, caſt off two couple, foot if at bottom, dance corners—

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: I ſhall be glad to ſpeak a word with you in private.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Dance corners, I ſay, out at ſides, croſs over, turn your partner, right hand and left.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Shall us dance it this evening, Sir Philip?

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, this evening.—But come, the hour draws nigh.—For ſhame, lads!—Wiſely, Bellfield, ye both live near my houſe;—come, and make ye ready.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: I can't go directly now.

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: You muſt; I have buſineſs with you.— [Aſide to Bellfield.] Lucinda ſhall be your own ſtill.—I have buſineſs with you too, Sir Philip.—Come, Bellfield, I inſiſt upon it. Forcing him off.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I attend you.—Careleſs, foot it at top, caſt off two couple. Dances out.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: An ungenerous woman to treat me thus!—I'll maſter up reſolution to deſpiſe her, and never converſe with her again.

div.stage: Enter HORTENSIA, and paſſes by him.
div.p: So, ſo, diſſembling woman! [looking after her.]

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Low, vile wretch!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: I'll not expoſtulate the matter with her.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: I'll not condeſcend to upbraid him.— [Goes up to him.] Mr. Careleſs, you're a villain.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: [Pretends to laugh.] Oh, Ma'am, I am fully acquainted with your ſentiments already.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: A cool, deliberate villain!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Unfeeling in all points of honour as in love.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Pleaſant, upon my ſoul!—She upbraids me too!

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: That unmanly ſneer!—Mr. Careleſs, Mr. Careleſs, after every proof of love a weak, inconſiderare woman could give—I will only now take the liberty to tell you, the baſeneſs of your heart will make you the averſion of our ſex, and the ſcorn of your own.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Since I muſt ſpeak, Heaven is my witneſs, I never fail'd in caution and reſpect for you; I never abuſed the confidence you repoſed in me; nobody breathing ever heard a ſyllable of our loves.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: No, Sir?

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: No; not a mortal.—You made me break off with Lucinda, and now—

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Could you favour me with a pinch of ſnuff?

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: I have not my box about me.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Shall I preſume to offer you a pinch of mine?

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: She's coming to again, by all that's tender!—Ha! ha!—I ſee how it is. [Aſide.]— [Turns to her.] You are very obliging.—How!

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Do you own your baſeneſs now?

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: How came that in your hands?

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: You could ſend it back with an affronting meſſage too.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: I, Ma'am!—By heaven, nobody ever handled it, or knew your picture was there, except my friend Wiſely.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Wiſely.—Excepting him, nobody ever—

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Oh, blockhead! fool! [Walks about.] You told him then?

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Yes, yes—I told him—I told him all—I deſired him to take it to town, and get it mended—I let him into the whole ſecret—I knew I could truſt him.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: The man on earth you ſhould not have truſted: He was your rival; and he contriv'd this miſchief. He ſent it back to me, as from you.—That's the uſe he has made of your confidence in him.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Oh! I ſee my folly.—Damnation!—And ſo the letter I receiv'd—

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Sir, I repent me of that letter.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: [Looking pleaſed.] Do you?

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Moſt heartily.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Bleſſings on you for the word.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: [Angry.] What, you are glad, are you?

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: To rapture.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: [With a ſneer.] I promiſe you, you ſhall never receive ſuch another.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Then I return it to you moſt joyfully.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Very well, Sir! you return a fond letter thus with ſcorn.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Fond do you call it?

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Was it no fondneſs to tell you here— [opens the letter.] What's this? oh, I ſee through this too! Now bluſh for your indiſcretion, weak, trifling man! This very letter I ſent Mr. Wiſely, when firſt my fooliſh heart ſeduc'd me to liſten to your addreſſes.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Shame and confuſion! ideot that I was!

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: How paltry do you appear now.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: I feel it all.—And yet will you ſuffer him, Wiſely, to ſucceed in ſo ungenerous a plot?

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: He has acted like a man of ſenſe: he has at once ſhewn me his own prudence, and the infirmity of your frivolous mind.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: But in all my conduct you ſee no marks of guilt, no treachery, no—

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Sir, it is to me the ſame thing if an idle imbecility of underſtanding aſſumes the appearance, or acts the purpoſes, of every vice in its turn.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: And can you thus, for a ſmall failure—

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: Small failure do you call it? Mr. Wiſely has deſerv'd me, and I'll beſtow myſelf upon him this very day, to ſhew the value I have for the man who has honour enough to keep a woman's ſecrets, and the contempt due to the wretch who, like you, can trifle with a generous heart.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Hell and the devil! I ſhall never be able to ſhew my face after this:—Blunt will rail at me, my enemies will rejoice, and every female tongue will clack, clack.—Confuſion!—What's to be done?—I'll follow her to Sir Philip's maſk; and from this moment not one unguarded word ſhall ever eſcape me. Exit.

div.stage: SCENE a Room in Sir Philip's Houſe.
Enter Sir PHILIP, WISELY, and BELLFIELD.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: You amaze me, Mr. Wiſely.—Careleſs a deſign upon my wife!

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: He has laid his plot as I have told you.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Why this is enough to ſpoil a man's dancing indeed. [Dances.]

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: Be directed by me, and you ſhall at once have full proof, and be able to prevent the miſchief.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: [Dancing.] I was never ſo diſconcerted in my born days.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Your own eyes, your own ears, ſhall convince you.—Wiſely, [aſide to Wiſely] I'll ſtep and ſee if Lucinda's ready.

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: [Aſide to Bellfield.] Does ſhe enter with ſpirit into the ſcheme?

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Moſt chearfully.

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: Well, ſtep and ſpeak to her once more. [Exit Bellfield.] This will finiſh him with Hortenſia. [Aſide.]—The levity of this man, Sir Philip, his own folly, has put it in my power to do you this ſervice.—Huſh! I ſee Careleſs coming; I know his dreſs.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: And there's comes my wife; I know her dreſs too.

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: Sir Philip, get you behind that curtain:—quick—quick;—your happineſs depends upon it.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: I am gone. [Goes behind the curtain hanging to the back ſcene.]

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: Now, now, this is the very criſis of his fate.

div.stage: Enter CARELESS and LUCINDA, at oppoſite doors, both maſked.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Her ladyſhip is true to her appointment, I ſee. [Unmaſks.]—My lady Figurein, this is generous indeed.

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: The ball-room's full. [In a feign'd voice.]

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: And we are ſafe here.—Come, come, let me hear the gentle accents of your own ſweet voice.

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: No; I love to practiſe.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: [Peeping behind.] I never knew ſuch perfidy in my life.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Now then the opportunity favours—let us retire to compleat each others' bliſs.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: You ſhall dance [ſinks and riſes] to another tune preſently.

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: I've ſomething to ſay to you firſt:—I hear you're going to marry that flirt, Lucinda.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Lucinda!—Ha! ha!—That will never be!—Marry her!—A proud inſolent, who over-rates both her beauty and her fortune.—I never had a ſincere regard for her; I gave the girl hopes, and pamper'd her vain imagination, but I never liked her.

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: I am glad to hear that;—I am afraid her character is not the beſt.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: If it has a flaw, ſhe uſes it like broken china; patches it up as well as ſhe can, and turns the faireſt ſide to view.

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: But then you'll marry Hortenſia.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: That will be as things happen.—But as to her, ſhe'll be of no inconvenience to our amours; I ſhall always be able to detach a part of my time from her, in order to dedicate it more happily to love and joy with your ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Such a villain never entered a gentleman's houſe!

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: I am very faint of a ſudden.—Throw up that window yonder.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Don't alarm yourſelf. [Drawing up the curtain, and looking towards her.] Your ladyſhip will be well in a moment.—Sir Philip will never ſuſpect, or be able to find us out. He'll be buſy with the graces.— [Making faſt the ſtring of the curtain, ſees him.] Damnation! [Walks away.]

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: [Following him.] Mr. Careleſs, this is the vileſt proceeding—the baſeſt uſage, Sir—the wickedeſt dsſign—it's enough to put a body in a paſſion.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Zoons! what ſhall I do now?

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: I did not think you capable of this—nor your ladyſhip either:—Come, ſhew your face, madam, and let me ſee how guilt becomes it.— [Takes off her maſk.] Lucinda all this time!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: How!—This is worſe and worſe.

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: Yes, Sir Philip, the gay, the giddy Lucinda.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: And my wife innocent all the time!

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: Entirely:—We concerted this ſcheme amongſt ourſelves to detect that gentleman.—Mr. Careleſs, you never had a ſincere regard for me, I think; and I have a flaw in my character, have not I?—Ha! ha!—Poor, detected Mr. Careleſs.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: I deſerve it all—I brought it all on myſelf.
Your humble ſervant, Mr. Careleſs.—Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: A ſwarm of enemies all at work againſt me.—This is your damn'd deſigning head, Wiſely.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Mr. Careleſs, [in a minuet ſtep] this is the groſſeſt violation of all friendſhip, honour, and hoſpitality—and, Sir, I ſhall hope to ſee you no more in my houſe.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: I ſhall take another opportunity to explain this matter, Sir Philip; and for the preſent I— [going].
She too here!—Oh, I'm in high luck!

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: Hortenſia, here has been ſuch a diſcovery!

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: I have heard it all, my dear—I have been attending in the next room.—Mr. Careleſs, what muſt I think of you now?

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Every thing that's harſh, I make no doubt.—Blunt, you ſee what a condition I'm in here.

sp.speaker: BLUNT.
sp.p: I knew you'd be a bankrupt in fame as well as love at laſt.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! I can't ſtand it—it's too much to bear.—I here take my leave of ye all. [Going]

sp.speaker: HORTENSIA.
sp.p: No, Sir, your preſence is neceſſary:—You ſhall be a witneſs to an act of juſtice.—Mr. Wiſely, I now acknowledge before this company, that I have behaved indelicately to you:—But now Sir, without ceremony, I give you my hand; at once to make atonement for my paſt conduct, and to ſhew that wretch the juſt reward of ſecrecy in love.

sp.speaker: WISELY.
sp.p: Generous Hortenſia!

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: And, to do full and ample juſtice on him, Mr. Bellfield, I have been a very tyrant to you. I have uſed you like—What was your ſimile, Mr. Careleſs?—My airs were too thin for a lover to ſubſiſt upon; and ſo now I'll let in a little common-ſenſe to keep him alive—Here, take me, Mr. Bellfield, that the gentleman may alſo ſee the juſt reward of ſincerity in love.

sp.speaker: BELLFIELD.
sp.p: Then I am paid indeed.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Poor Careleſs! I almoſt pity him.—He has had his dance, and now he pays the piper.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Oh, mighty well!—you may laugh.—I ſhall leave ye in poſſeſſion of your mirth. [Throwing off his maſk.] Ha! ha!—I fancy, though, you'll ſee that I can meet with a ſucceſs elſewhere equal to any of ye.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Ay, ay, go on—enjoy the joke:——I ſhan't drop the leaſt hint of my future ſchemes; but I believe—

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Poor Careleſs!—Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: In a little time you'll know it all.—I ſhall depart for the county of Norfolk; and you may poſſibly read, in a few days, in the Norwich Journal, of Miſs Belvidere and your humble ſervant—That's all.

sp.speaker: LUCINDA.
sp.p: O brave! a ſieve to the very laſt.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: I have known them dance fifty couple at the Norwich aſſembly.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: Well, well; I'll ſay no more. [Going.]

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: [Stopping him.] Mr. Careleſs, ſince no injury is done me, I am willing to hope this day's buſineſs will correct your future conduct.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: You are very good, Sir Philip.—It will be a leſſon to me for the reſt of my life.

sp.speaker: SIR PHILIP.
sp.p: Then let us dance away reflection for the precent.—I won't be diſappointed:—You ſhall ſacrifice to the graces with me.

sp.speaker: CARELESS.
sp.p: With all my heart:—I have no ill will to any one.—Wiſely, I deſerve it, for putting myſelf in your power.—Blunt, ſpare my confuſion.—I have been a very ſilly fellow:—But ſince things are come to this iſſue, I have the conſolation to feel, that whatever may have been my indiſcretions, I am greatly above a ſelfiſh and ungenerous character: I ſcorn a baſe action as much as any man in England.
sp.l: The careleſs indiſcreet (this day has ſhewn)
Is no One's Enemy except His Own.
